headline: Marinated Cucumber, Onion, and Tomato Salad
description: This summer-ready cucumber, tomato, and onion salad is marinated for two hours in a simple, zesty homemade dressing before it's served for tons of flavor.

video.description: Tomatoes, cucumbers, and onions make a fresh summer salad!
video.name: Marinated Cucumber, Onion, and Tomato Salad

name: Marinated Cucumber, Onion, and Tomato Salad
recipeIngredient: 1 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, or to taste
1 onion, sliced and separated into rings

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk water, vinegar, oil, sugar, salt, and pepper together in a large bowl until smooth.
Add cucumbers, tomatoes, and onion and stir to coat.
Cover bowl with plastic wrap; refrigerate for at least 2 hours.

That being said, my mother learned how to cook from her and I learned how to cook for my mother. Fried chicken, fresh green beans and potatoes cooked and salt pork, cornbread, sliced tomatoes and a very similar version of this salad.... apple cider vinegar, sugar, salt, black pepper, Vidalia onions, cucumbers and water. If we were lucky.....blackberry cobbler for dessert.

I couldn't even wait for the 2 hours to marinate, lol! I dug in right away and ate some. I used olive oil and rice vinegar with my cucumbers and roma tomatoes freshly picked from my garden. Also a half Walla Walla sweet onion. I cut them up into bite sized pieces. I used about 1/8 cup raw agave nectar instead of sugar as it mixes better. And I added about 1 tablespoon dried basil, some minced fresh garlic, along with pink himalayan salt and fresh pepper. What's left (lol!) is now marinating in the frig. It can only get better! Yum!!!

I didn't have 2 hours to chill but was able to chill for an hour in the fridge and I did add some chopped romaine lettuce that added some interest. I definitely will make this salad again and tucked the recipe away in a safe place. Give it a try I can say it was delicious

I usually make this a day before serving, so the flavors can mix, and the dressing infuses into the veggies a bit. Delish!

We add safflower oil and a wee bit of lime and orange zest with a few thin julienne strips. It is part of our antipasti dishes.

Biggest flaw with this recipe is that the cukes were not sweated first. If you don‚Äôt, you‚Äôll have a watery mess. Peel and cut cukes and place in a colander over an empty pot. Sprinkle liberally with salt and let sit for 2 hours. Press down with a paper towel to get out all the water and discard liquid. Now you can proceed with the rest of the recipe.
